newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission sees mixed success for third aviation package.
newsitem.headline: Commission sees mixed success for third aviation package.

text.p: "Not bad but could do better" appears to be the conclusion of a European Commission report, due to be adopted on Tuesday on airlines' response to the the third package of aviation liberalisations.
"The majority of fares have come down substantially but there's still a part of the market which remains very stubborn," a Commission spokeswoman told Reuters on Monday.

She was speaking ahead of Tuesday's expected adoption of a report on the state of progress in advance of next April's planned full liberalisation of aviation traffic rights for airlines based within the European Union.
"The whole idea of the report is to put some facts and figures behind anecdotal complaints about (airlines') abuses of dominant positions or excessive fares," she said.

"We want to look again at those routes which seem particularly over-priced or where duopolies have replaced monopolies with no particular signs that there are any changes in fares," said the spokeswoman, without giving further detail.

While gradual changes during the last 10 years have brought west European passengers greater flexibility in choosing routes, flight times and cheaper fare options, fully flexible fares remain high for those travelling at the last minute.

"There has been no dramatic decrease in fares, no spectacular disappearance of major carriers, no substantial penetration of domestic markets by foreign competitors," European Commission official Philip Lowe said in a recent speech on the subject in Brussels.
"Whilst the effects of liberalisation are now noticeable, they are appearing slowly," said Lowe, chef de cabinet to Transport Commissioner Neil Kinnock.
He singled out domestic routes in Germany, France and Italy as ones where fares remained very high compared with the United States, where deregulation took place in the late 1970s.
